Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Use the conjecture about the sum of angle of a quadrilateral equals 360° to write an equation for each quadrilateral. Then solve the equation to find the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>. Use a protractor to check the reasonableness of your answer.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Use the conjecture about the sum of angle of a quadrilateral equals 360° to write an equation for each quadrilateral. Then solve the equation to find the value of  x. Use a protractor to check the reasonableness of your answer.

Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to communicate precisely. You also need to state the meanings of the symbols you use.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Write an inequality for each graph. Then, in words, describe all the values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> that make each inequality true.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Write an inequality for each graph. Then, in words, describe all the values of x that make each inequality true.

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text:
To be proficient in math,
you need to identify and
analyze important
relationships and then
draw conclusions, using
tools such as diagrams,
flowcharts, and formulas.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. The National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) uses the following formula to rank the passing efficiencies <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>P</mi></math> of quarterbacks. <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac bevelled="true"><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>Y</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><mn>100</mn><mi>C</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><mn>330</mn><mi>T</mi><mo> </mo><mo>-</mo><mo> </mo><mn>200</mn><mi>N</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>A</mi></mfrac></math>. Determine whether each inequality must be true. Explain your reasoning.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. The National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) uses the following formula to rank the passing efficiencies P of quarterbacks. P is equal to start fraction 8 point 4 y plus 100 C plus 330 T minus 200 N over A end fraction. Determine whether each inequality must be true. Explain your reasoning.

Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Use the passing efficiency formula to create a passing record that makes each inequality true. Record your results in the table. Then describe the values of P that make each inequality true. <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>​</mo><mo> </mo><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>8</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>Y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>100</mn><mi>C</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>330</mn><mi>T</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>200</mn><mi>N</mi></mstyle><mi>A</mi></mfrac></math>

Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to create a clear representation of the problem at hand.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. In parts (a)–(d), use two inequalities to describe the interval.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. In parts a to d, use two inequalities to describe the interval.

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. Functions can be described in many ways.
● by an equation
● by an input-output table
● using words
● by a graph
● as a set of ordered pairs
 Explain why the graph shown represents a function.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Functions can be described in many ways. by an equation, by an input-output table, using words, by a graph, as a set of ordered pairs. Explain why the graph shown represents a function.

Sheet1.Caption: Describe the function in two other ways.
Sheet1.VO: Describe the function in two other ways.

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Find the slope and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>-intercept of each line.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Find the slope and y-intercept of each line.

Sheet1.Caption: No
Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to justify your conclusions and communicate them to others.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Does the graph represent <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math> as a function of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>? Justify your conclusion.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Does the graph represent y as a function of  x? Justify your conclusion.

Sheet1.Caption: What is the value of the function when <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>? How can you tell?
Sheet1.VO: What is the value of the function when x is equal to 0? How can you tell?

Sheet1.Caption: Write an equation that represents the values of the function when <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo> </mo><mi>x</mi><mo> </mo><mo>≤</mo><mo> </mo><mn>0</mn></math>.
Sheet1.VO: Write an equation that represents the values of the function when x is less than or equal to 0 .

Sheet1.Caption: Write an equation that represents the values of the function when  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo> </mo><mo>></mo><mo> </mo><mn>0</mn></math> .
Sheet1.VO: Write an equation that represents the values of the function when x is greater than 0.

Sheet1.Caption: Combine the results of parts (c) and (d) to write a single description of the function.
Sheet1.VO: Combine the results of parts c and d to write a single description of the function.

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Does the graph represent <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math> as a function of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>? Justify your conclusion.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner.,Does the graph represent y as a function of x? Justify your conclusion.

Sheet1.Caption: Describe the values of the function for the following intervals.
Sheet1.VO: Describe the values of the function for the following intervals.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Writing a System of Linear Equations
Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Your family opens a bed-and-breakfast. They spend $600 preparing a bedroom to rent. The cost to your family for food and utilities is $15 per night. They charge $75 per night to rent the bedroom. Write an equation that represents the costs. Cost, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>C</mi></math>  (in dollars)  =  $15 per night <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo> </mo><mo>⋅</mo></math> Number of nights, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo> </mo></math> + $600
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Your family opens a bed-and-breakfast. They spend 600 dollars preparing a bedroom to rent. The cost to your family for food and utilities is 15 dollars per night. They charge 75 dollars per night to rent the bedroom. Write an equation that represents the costs. Cost, C (in dollars) = 15 dollars per night times Number of nights, x plus 600 dollars.

Sheet1.Caption: Write an equation that represents the revenue (income). Revenue,  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>R</mi></math> (in dollars) = $75 per night  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>⋅</mo></math>  Number of nights,  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>
Sheet1.VO: Write an equation that represents the revenue (income). Revenue,  R (in dollars) = 75 dollars per night  times Number of nights,x

Sheet1.Caption: A set of two (or more) linear equations is called a system of linear equations. Write the system of linear equations for this problem.
Sheet1.VO: A set of two (or more) linear equations is called a system of linear equations. Write the system of linear equations for this problem.

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. Solve each system of linear equations using two methods. Method 1 Solve for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> first. Method 2 Solve for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math> first. Is the solution the same using both methods? Explain which method you would prefer
to use for each system.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. Solve each system of linear equations using two methods. Method 1 Solve for x first. Method 2 Solve for y first.
Is the solution the same using both methods? Explain which method you would prefer to use for each system.

Sheet1.Caption: No
Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Caption: No
Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Expl Title: Writing and Solving a System of Equations
Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. You purchase a drink and a sandwich for $4.50. Your friend purchases a drink and five sandwiches for $16.50. You want to determine the price of a drink and the price of a sandwich. Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> represent the price (in dollars) of one drink. Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math> represent the price
(in dollars) of one sandwich. Write a system of equations for the situation. Use the following verbal model. Number of drinks <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>·</mo></math> Price per drink <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>+</mo></math> Number of sandwiches <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>·</mo></math> Price per sandwich <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>=</mo></math> Total price.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. You purchase a drink and a sandwich for 4 dollars 50 cents. Your friend purchases a drink and five sandwiches for 16 dollars 50 cents. You want to determine the price of a drink and the price of a sandwich.

Let x represent the price (in dollars) of one drink. Let y represent the price (in dollars) of one sandwich. Write a system of equations for the situation. Use the following verbal model.

Number of drinks times Price per drink  plus Number of sandwiches times Price per sandwich is equal to Total price.

Sheet1.Caption: Subtract Equation 1 from Equation 2.
Sheet1.VO: Subtract Equation 1 from Equation 2.

Sheet1.Caption: Explain how you can use the result to solve the system of equations.
Sheet1.VO: Explain how you can use the result to solve the system of equations.

Sheet1.Caption: Find and interpret the solution.
Sheet1.VO: Find and interpret the solution.

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text:
To be proficient in math,
you need to monitor and
evaluate your progress
and change course using
a different solution
method, if necessary.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Solve each system of linear equations using two methods. Method 1 Subtract. Subtract Equation 2 from Equation 1. Then use the result to solve the system. Method 2 Add. Add the two equations. Then use the result to solve the system. Is the solution the same using both methods? Which method do you prefer?
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Solve each system of linear equations using two methods. Method 1 Subtract. Subtract Equation 2 from Equation 1. Then use the result to solve the system. Method 2 Add. Add the two equations. Then use the result to solve the system. Is the solution the same using both methods? Which method do you prefer?

Sheet1.Caption: No
Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Caption: No
Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Expl Title: Using Elimination to Solve a System
Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><mi>y</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mn>7</mn></math> <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><mn>5</mn><mi>y</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mn>17</mn></math>. Can you eliminate a variable by adding or subtracting the equations as they are?
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. 2 x plus y is equal to 7. x plus 5 y is equal to 17. Can you eliminate a variable by adding or subtracting the equations as they are?

Sheet1.Caption: If not, what do you need to do to one or both equations so that you can?
Sheet1.VO: If not, what do you need to do to one or both equations so that you can?

Sheet1.Caption: Solve the system individually. Then exchange solutions with your partner and compare and check the solutions.
Sheet1.VO: Solve the system individually. Then exchange solutions with your partner and compare and check the solutions.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Writing a Linear Inequality in Two Variables
Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Write an equation represented by the dashed line.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Write an equation represented by the dashed line.

Sheet1.Caption: The solutions of an inequality are represented by the shaded region. In words, describe the solutions of the inequality.
Sheet1.VO: The solutions of an inequality are represented by the shaded region. In words, describe the solutions of the inequality.

Sheet1.Caption: Write an inequality represented by the graph. Which inequality symbol did you use? Explain your reasoning.
Sheet1.VO: Write an inequality represented by the graph. Which inequality symbol did you use? Explain your reasoning.

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Name: LOOKING FOR REGULARITY IN REPEATED REASONING
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text:
To be proficient in math, you need to notice
whether calculations are repeated and look for both general methods and shortcuts.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Write a cube root function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math>, that has the given values. Then use the function to complete the table.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Write a cube root function, y is equal to f of x, that has the given values. Then use the function to complete the table.

Sheet1.Caption: No
Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Match each radical equation with the graph of its related radical function.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Match each radical equation with the graph of its related radical function.

Sheet1.Caption: Explain your reasoning. Then use the graph to solve the equation, if possible. Check your solutions.
Sheet1.VO: Explain your reasoning. Then use the graph to solve the equation, if possible. Check your solutions.

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. The table shows the length <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> (in inches) and the width <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math> (in inches) of a rectangle. The area of each rectangle is 64 square inches.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. The table shows the length x (in inches) and the width y (in inches) of a rectangle. The area of each rectangle is 64 square inches. Complete the table.

Sheet1.Caption: Describe the relationship between <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>. Explain why <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math> is said to vary inversely with <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>.
Sheet1.VO: Describe the relationship between x and y. Explain why y is said to vary inversely with x.

Sheet1.Caption: Draw a scatter plot of the data. What are the characteristics of the graph?
Sheet1.VO: Draw a scatter plot of the data. What are the characteristics of the graph?

Sheet1.Caption: Write an equation that represents <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math> as a function of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>.
Sheet1.VO: Write an equation that represents y as a function of x.

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Two six-sided dice are rolled, experimentally estimate the probability that the sum of the two numbers rolled is 7. Describe your experiment
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Two six-sided dice are rolled, experimentally estimate the probability that the sum of the two numbers rolled is 7. Describe your experiment

Sheet1.Caption: Six pieces of paper, numbered 1 through 6, are in a bag. Two pieces of paper are selected one at a time without replacement. Experimentally estimate the probability that the sum of the two numbers selected is 7. Describe your experiment.
Sheet1.VO: Six pieces of paper, numbered 1 through 6, are in a bag. Two pieces of paper are selected one at a time without replacement. Experimentally estimate the probability that the sum of the two numbers selected is 7. Describe your experiment.

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. In many naturally occurring data sets, the histogram of the data is bell-shaped. In statistics, such data sets are said to have a normal distribution. For the normal distribution shown below, estimate the percent of the data that lies within one, two, and three standard deviations of the mean. Each square on the grid represents 1%.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. In many naturally occurring data sets, the histogram of the data is bell-shaped. In statistics, such data sets are said to have a normal distribution. For the normal distribution shown below, estimate the percent of the data that lies within one, two, and three standard deviations of the mean. Each square on the grid represents 1%.

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to analyze relationships mathematically to draw conclusions.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. A famous data set was collected in  Scotland in the mid-1800s. It contains the chest sizes (in inches) of 5738 men in the Scottish Militia. Do the data fit a normal distribution? Explain.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. A famous data set was collected in  Scotland in the mid-1800s. It contains the chest sizes (in inches) of 5738 men in the Scottish Militia. Do the data fit a normal distribution? Explain.

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to justify your conclusions and communicate them to others.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Determine whether each sample is representative of the population. To determine the number of hours people exercise during a week, researchers use random-digit dialing and call 1500 people. Explain your reasoning.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Determine whether each sample is representative of the population. To determine the number of hours people exercise during a week, researchers use random-digit dialing and call 1500 people. Explain your reasoning.

Sheet1.Caption: To determine how many text messages high school students send in a week, researchers post a survey on a website and receive 750 responses.
Sheet1.VO: To determine how many text messages high school students send in a week, researchers post a survey on a website and receive 750 responses.

Sheet1.Caption: To determine how much money college students spend on clothes each semester, a researcher surveys 450 college students as they leave the university library.
Sheet1.VO: To determine how much money college students spend on clothes each semester, a researcher surveys 450 college students as they leave the university library.

Sheet1.Caption: To determine the quality of service customers receive, an airline sends an e-mail survey to each customer after the completion of a flight.
Sheet1.VO: To determine the quality of service customers receive, an airline sends an e-mail survey to each customer after the completion of a flight.

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Determine whether each survey question is biased. Explain your reasoning. If so, suggest an unbiased rewording of the question. Does eating nutritious, whole-grain foods improve your health?
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Determine whether each survey question is biased. Explain your reasoning. If so, suggest an unbiased rewording of the question. Does eating nutritious, whole-grain foods improve your health?

Sheet1.Caption: Do you ever attempt the dangerous activity of texting while driving?
Sheet1.VO: Do you ever attempt the dangerous activity of texting while driving?

Sheet1.Caption: How many hours do you sleep each night?
Sheet1.VO: How many hours do you sleep each night?

Sheet1.Caption: How can the mayor of your city improve his or her public image?
Sheet1.VO: How can the mayor of your city improve his or her public image?

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. Discuss each potential problem in obtaining a random survey
of a population. Include suggestions for overcoming the problem. The people selected might not be a random sample of the population.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Discuss each potential problem in obtaining a random survey of a population. Include suggestions for overcoming the problem. The people selected might not be a random sample of the population.

Sheet1.Caption: The people selected might not be willing to participate in the survey.
Sheet1.VO: The people selected might not be willing to participate in the survey.

Sheet1.Caption: The people selected might not be truthful when answering the question.
Sheet1.VO: The people selected might not be truthful when answering the question.

Sheet1.Caption: The people selected might not understand the survey question.
Sheet1.VO: The people selected might not understand the survey question.

Sheet1.Expl Title:
Determining Whether a Statement Is
True or False
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. A hypothesis can either be true or false. The same is true of a conclusion. For a conditional statement to be true, the hypothesis and conclusion do not necessarily both have to be true. Determine whether each conditional statement is true or false. Justify your answer. 
If yesterday was Wednesday, then today is Thursday.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. A hypothesis can either be true or false. The same is true of a conclusion. For a conditional statement to be true, the hypothesis and conclusion do not necessarily both have to be true. Determine whether each conditional statement is true or false. Justify your answer. 
If yesterday was Wednesday, then today is Thursday.

Sheet1.Caption: If an angle is acute, then it has a measure of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>30</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
Sheet1.VO: If an angle is acute, then it has a measure of 30 degrees.

Sheet1.Caption: If a month has 30 days, then it is June.
Sheet1.VO: If a month has 30 days, then it is June.

Sheet1.Caption: If an even number is not divisible by 2, then 9 is a perfect cube.
Sheet1.VO: If an even number is not divisible by 2, then 9 is a perfect cube.

Sheet1.Expl Title:
Determining Whether a Statement Is
True or False
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. Use the points in the
coordinate plane to determine whether each
statement is true or false. Justify your answer.
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∆</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is a right triangle.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. Use the points in the
coordinate plane to determine whether each
statement is true or false. Justify your answer.
Triangle ABC is a right triangle.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∆</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is an equilateral triangle.
Sheet1.VO: Triangle BDC is an equilateral triangle.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∆</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is an isosceles triangle.
Sheet1.VO: Triangle BDC is an isosceles triangle.

Sheet1.Caption: Quadrilateral <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is a trapezoid.
Sheet1.VO: Quadrilateral ABCD is a trapezoid.

Sheet1.Caption: Quadrilateral <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is a parallelogram.
Sheet1.VO: Quadrilateral ABCD is a parallelogram.

Sheet1.Expl Title:
Determining Whether a Statement Is
True or False
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed.
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. Determine whether each conditional statement is true or false.
Justify your answer.
If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∆</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>C</mi></math> ADC is a right triangle, then the Pythagorean Theorem is valid for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∆</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>C</mi></math> ADC.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. Determine whether each conditional statement is true or false.
Justify your answer.
If triangle ADC is a right triangle, then the Pythagorean Theorem is valid for triangle ADC.

Sheet1.Caption: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∠</mo><mi>B</mi></math> are complementary, then the sum of their measures is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
Sheet1.VO: If angle A and angle B are complementary, then the sum of their measures is 180 degrees.

Sheet1.Caption: If figure ABCD is a quadrilateral, then the sum of its angle measures is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
Sheet1.VO: If figure ABCD is a quadrilateral, then the sum of its angle measures is 180 degrees.

Sheet1.Caption: If points <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>C</mi></math> are collinear, then they lie on the same line.
Sheet1.VO: If points A, B, and C are collinear, then they lie on the same line.

Sheet1.Caption: If line <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> and line <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> intersect at a point, then they form two pairs of vertical angles.
Sheet1.VO: If line AB and line BD intersect at a point, then they form two pairs of vertical angles.
